The Boosters Club, for the third
consecutive year, is sponsoring a
tour of the Hopkins Hospital and
Medical School next Wednesday.
Buses will leave Levering Hall
at one p.m. Students may sign up
for the tour on sheets provided in
the Gilman basement, or in the
dormitory post office.
Sandy Cohen, president of the
Boosters, commented, "Twice the
year before, and once last year, we
have conducted these tours. Officials of the hospital conduct the
tours through wards, laboratories,
and operating rooms. On all three
previous occasions, 50 or 60 people
took the tour, and an enjoyable
time was had by all."

are Dunn, 596; Gallagher, 2023;

"We could take advantage of
the News-Letter's printing this
and ramble on for a few more
pages, but we feel that it would be
better if you, the students, read
the thing yourselves. Granted, it's
not as absorbing as Playboy,
Mickey Spillane, or Morrill's
analytic text, but please read it
anyhow."

NEWSPAPER ADVERTISING
.a rewarding career for active minds
and
Just as news and editorials have their impact on the social
political life of a community, so advertising affects economic trends.
Newspaper advertising helps business and industry grow. As commerce
expands, so prospers the nation.
To be a human factor in this great force is a tremendous challenge.
of
Although the press basically is a medium for the dissemination
to
news, more than half the space contained in newspapers is devoted
er
newspap
daily
a
of
staff
sing
advertising. The worker on the adverti
experiences all the thrills known to the reporter and the editor.
Printer's ink gets in his blood, though primarily he's a sales representative.
s
Because of his daily contacts the newspaper advertising man acquire
a knowledge of more different kinds of businesses than would be possible in any other field of endeavor.
Scouting an elusive prospect for the restaurant column; planning a
series of ads for the construction industry or Liking business; consulting with a department store executive about a month-end clearance—it's all in the day's work!
Newspaper advertising is no sedentary occupation. If you like to meet
sitting
people, if you like getting out and moving around rather than
comfortably by, you'll like the opportunity for progress and service
that it offers. And Kipling might have added,
If you're poetic and a sort of artist,
And yet possess a Machiavellian strain
That makes you fully conscious of the dollar,
Yet know that pennies keep away the rain...
adverIf you like "doing things" in the world of business—newspaper
tising is for you!

The House Of Lords

vacuum, occupied for the
most part with such activities as contemplating its own
constitution.
The fact is, the traditional scope for a Student Council
is not to be found at Hopkins. Councils at other schools are
concerned with mediating between administration and students on the relaxation or tightening of rules. and regulations. Since the student here is given the highest degree of
personal freedom, there is little such work for the JHU body.
The elected Student Council is a traditional thing, how,ever, and will probably remain, even though members themselves concede that the elections are "popularity contests"
not based on aptitude or ability. It would be well to bring
the SC into closer touch with reality, as Dr. Morrill suggests,
by having the campus leaders present (though—we urge—
not voting), but to oust them from their specialized and often
well-managed Offices for missing a couple of SC meetings
would be a serious blunder.

Paul Guild, E.E., Purdue, '49,
started as a student engineer with
Long Lines—the Bell System unit that
interconnects Bell Telephone Companies. In the student training program he became familiar with all
operations of the business.
After that he spent two years on
technical and engineering projects
that took him to Indianapolis, Cleveland and Atlanta.
March of 1953 found Paul in Cincinnati working on the construction
of radio relay routes. He worked with
the newest microwave equipment that

transmits television pictures and telephone conversations simultaneously.
In 1955, as part of his further
development, Paul was transferred to
a completely different assignment. He
now supervises the important planning job of balancing a working force
of 900 Long Distance operators with
the ever-changing work load.
"I use my engineering background
on this job, too," says Paul. "It's
extremely interesting and has lots of
responsibility. Besides, you need experience in more than one department to give you background."

Paul Guild is typical of young engineers in the Bell
System. Similar career opportunities exist in the Bell
Telephone Companies, Bell Telephone Laboratories,
Western Electric and Sandia Corporation. Your placement officer has more information on these companies.

Fencemen Out To Repeat
Mid-Atlantic Tourney Wins

Varsity Fencing Coach
Schlick has expressed optimism
over this year's fencing squad
stating that the team has great
potential and should be strengthened by some of last season's
freshman swordsmen.
Seeking to retire the Yale Tro-

Pershing Rifles
Win Dril) Prize
Johns Hopkins Pershing Rifles
and their newly-named pledges
were awarded first place in the
Parkville Armistice Day Military
Reserve Unit competition.
A trophy was awarded to the
company, signifying superiority
performance over the 17 other
units in the parade. Twenty-nine
pledges were initiated into the organization immediately before the

phy, emblematic of Middle-Atlantic Conference Fencing Championship, the Jays are bolstered by a
number of returning lettermen.
Three lettermen head the sabre
division—John Forte, Dick Heckman, and Daryl Carter. Forte and
Heckman have both been members
of the squad which has copped the
Middle-Atlantic Sabre Trophy for
the past two years.
Al Rose, former Baltimore and
Washington epee champion who
was ineligible last year, heads that
division which includes Tom Feher, Joe Rifkin, and Bill Zequna.
Dick Everett, Fred Rosenbloom,
Jim Perce, and Frank Rosensweig
will represent the Jays in the foil
division.
The schedule includes six Middle-Atlantic Conference matches
and a match with Navy. Haverford, Temple, and Swarthmore are
three of the traditional MiddleAtlantic opponents.
All those interested in the freshman fencing team should meet today in the gym. Bill Strutton,
freshman coach, urges all interested, regardless of experience, to attend.

The Boosters Club, for the third
consecutive year, is sponsoring a
tour of the Hopkins Hospital and
Medical School next Wednesday.
Buses will leave Levering Hall
at one p.m. Students may sign up
for the tour on sheets provided in
the Gilman basement, or in the
dormitory post office.
Sandy Cohen, president of the
Boosters, commented, "Twice the
year before, and once last year, we
have conducted these tours. Officials of the hospital conduct the
tours through wards, laboratories,
and operating rooms. On all three
previous occasions, 50 or 60 people
took the tour, and an enjoyable
time was had by all."

analytic text, but please read it
anyhow."

NEWSPAPER ADVERTISING
.a rewarding career for active minds
and
Just as news and editorials have their impact on the social
political life of a community, so advertising affects economic trends.
Newspaper advertising helps business and industry grow. As commerce
expands, so prospers the nation.
To be a human factor in this great force is a tremendous challenge.
of
Although the press basically is a medium for the dissemination
to
news, more than half the space contained in newspapers is devoted
er
newspap
daily
a
of
staff
sing
advertising. The worker on the adverti
experiences all the thrills known to the reporter and the editor.
Printer's ink gets in his blood, though primarily he's a sales representative.
s
Because of his daily contacts the newspaper advertising man acquire
a knowledge of more different kinds of businesses than would be possible in any other field of endeavor.
Scouting an elusive prospect for the restaurant column; planning a
series of ads for the construction industry or Liking business; consulting with a department store executive about a month-end clearance—it's all in the day's work!
Newspaper advertising is no sedentary occupation. If you like to meet
sitting
people, if you like getting out and moving around rather than
comfortably by, you'll like the opportunity for progress and service
that it offers. And Kipling might have added,
If you're poetic and a sort of artist,
And yet possess a Machiavellian strain
That makes you fully conscious of the dollar,
Yet know that pennies keep away the rain...
adverIf you like "doing things" in the world of business—newspaper
tising is for you!

The House Of Lords

vacuum, occupied for the
most part with such activities as contemplating its own
constitution.
The fact is, the traditional scope for a Student Council
is not to be found at Hopkins. Councils at other schools are
concerned with mediating between administration and students on the relaxation or tightening of rules. and regulations. Since the student here is given the highest degree of
personal freedom, there is little such work for the JHU body.
The elected Student Council is a traditional thing, how,ever, and will probably remain, even though members themselves concede that the elections are "popularity contests"
not based on aptitude or ability. It would be well to bring
the SC into closer touch with reality, as Dr. Morrill suggests,
by having the campus leaders present (though—we urge—
not voting), but to oust them from their specialized and often
well-managed Offices for missing a couple of SC meetings
would be a serious blunder.

Paul Guild, E.E., Purdue, '49,
started as a student engineer with
Long Lines—the Bell System unit that
interconnects Bell Telephone Companies. In the student training program he became familiar with all
operations of the business.
After that he spent two years on
technical and engineering projects
that took him to Indianapolis, Cleveland and Atlanta.
March of 1953 found Paul in Cincinnati working on the construction
of radio relay routes. He worked with
the newest microwave equipment that

transmits television pictures and telephone conversations simultaneously.
In 1955, as part of his further
development, Paul was transferred to
a completely different assignment. He
now supervises the important planning job of balancing a working force
of 900 Long Distance operators with
the ever-changing work load.
"I use my engineering background
on this job, too," says Paul. "It's
extremely interesting and has lots of
responsibility. Besides, you need experience in more than one department to give you background."

Paul Guild is typical of young engineers in the Bell
System. Similar career opportunities exist in the Bell
Telephone Companies, Bell Telephone Laboratories,
Western Electric and Sandia Corporation. Your placement officer has more information on these companies.

Pershing Rifles
Win Dril) Prize
Johns Hopkins Pershing Rifles
and their newly-named pledges
were awarded first place in the
Parkville Armistice Day Military
Reserve Unit competition.
A trophy was awarded to the
company, signifying superiority
performance over the 17 other
units in the parade. Twenty-nine
pledges were initiated into the organization immediately before the
parade and are now undergoing a
series of pledge classes.
The Pershing Rifle pledges are
W. E. Bartles, J. A. Benaglia, E. S.
Carr, R. C. Colonna, N. R. Cronquist, M. E. Dale, B. T. Devlin,
R. N. Emery, J. W. Erdman, L. J.
Flannery, L. H. Gibbons, W. B.
Keller, J. W. Lansch, M. W. Magruder, M. H. Miller, J. C. Mitchell,
Richardson,

G. H. Townsend, T. D. Toy, W. H.

J. R. Wilson.

phy, emblematic of Middle-Atlantic Conference Fencing Championship, the Jays are bolstered by a
number of returning lettermen.
Three lettermen head the sabre
division—John Forte, Dick Heckman, and Daryl Carter. Forte and
Heckman have both been members
of the squad which has copped the
Middle-Atlantic Sabre Trophy for
the past two years.
Al Rose, former Baltimore and
Washington epee champion who
was ineligible last year, heads that
division which includes Tom Feher, Joe Rifkin, and Bill Zequna.
Dick Everett, Fred Rosenbloom,
Jim Perce, and Frank Rosensweig
will represent the Jays in the foil
division.
The schedule includes six Middle-Atlantic Conference matches
and a match with Navy. Haverford, Temple, and Swarthmore are
three of the traditional MiddleAtlantic opponents.
All those interested in the freshman fencing team should meet today in the gym. Bill Strutton,
freshman coach, urges all interested, regardless of experience, to attend.
